name: All Below the Tower of Babel
name_original: All Below the Tower of Babel
description:
All Below the Tower of Babylon is a party-based card battler dungeon exploration text-based adventure game.  Boy, that's a lot of words and genres!  But don't take my word for it, play it for yourself.  You'll be welcomed into an alternative fantasy version of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East where the oldest empire never died, but grew on the backs of mythical creatures.

You play as the Runeseeker, and you create your character down to a trait, class, your gender and your race.  

Growing up, your mother told you old faerie tales about the runes that govern the status of the world.  One day, your world is split as when you were out getting water for your family, the Gaulian army invaded the netural town of Gaullia Celtia, and killed all the villagers, including your family.  Not knowing what to do, you venture to the town of Kastelstad, a realm self-managed by mercaneries.  On your 17th birthday, when you are of age, you decide to go ahead and see if there are any truth to those faerie tales.

All Below the Tower of Babel is currently in the alpha stage.  I plan on releasing 4 alphas, which focus on a certain aspect of the game.  The first alpha will be released soon, which will feature character creation, party recruitment, and dungeon exploration, only.

Alpha 2 will feature battling, Alpha 3 will feature the use of items, treasure and runes, and Alpha 4 will focus on the hub world and an actual basic game you can ply.

After the Alpha, I will be releasing betas periodically to focus on story elements and new dungeons.

If you want to join our Discord, this is where you can report bugs and get support.  You can join here: https://discord.gg/vAGFgh8yr8

I plan on releasing this game on Windows, OSX and Linux at first.  All prototypes will be Windows only.

Watch this space, because wonderous things will happen!

Note: for perservation's sake, game alphas and betas will always be kept here and will not be deleted.
